speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about the swelling in your neck, when did it start and has it changed in size or shape over time?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about 2 months ago, and to be honest, it's been steadily growing, but I hadn't really thought much of it until it started to notice it's getting a bit larger, it's not really changing shape, though."

speaker: Doctor
text: "When did the swelling start and has it changed in size or shape over time?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It's about 2 months ago, and to be honest, it's been steadily growing, but I hadn't really thought much of it until it started to notice it's getting a bit larger, it's not really changing shape, though."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you describe the sensation of the swelling? Is it painful to touch, or is it completely painless?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It's not really painful to the touch, but there's a slight tenderness, it's more of a dull ache, not sharp or stabbing. It's just a gentle feeling, but it's noticeable when I'm wearing my jacket or tie, it feels like it's pressing against my skin a bit."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about the swelling, is it tender to the touch, and have you noticed any warmth or redness around the area?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, it's a bit tender to the touch, like I mentioned earlier, it's not sharp or stabbing, but there's a dull ache, and when I'm wearing my jacket or tie, it feels like it's pressing against my skin a bit. As for warmth or redness, I haven't really noticed anything like that, it's just a steady, firm swelling, not anything that's changing color or temperature."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to perform a quick examination of the swelling to get a better look. May you please slowly turn your head to the side, and I'll take a closer look.

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll slowly turn my head to the side. *turns head slowly* Here, it's right here, where the swelling is. You can see it's quite noticeable now. It's a bit firm to the touch, like I mentioned earlier."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, I'd like to take a closer look. Can you slowly tilt your head to the other side, and I'll examine the swelling on the other side?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll tilt my head to the other side... *tilts head* Ah, yeah, I can see it's a bit symmetrical, same size and shape on the other side. It's still feeling a bit tender to the touch, but not sharp or stabbing, just a dull ache."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me if the swelling is more noticeable on one side of your neck compared to the other?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It's actually pretty much the same on both sides, to be honest, I didn't even notice a difference when I was tilting my head to the other side. It's just...I suppose I'm used to it being there, now."

speaker: Doctor
text: "I'd like to check the lymph nodes in your neck. Can you gently swallow for me? I need to check if the swelling is connected to the lymph nodes."

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll swallow... *swallows* Is that what you needed to check?"

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Can you describe the sensation of the swelling in more detail, is it hard, soft, or does it feel like a lump?"



"Is there any difficulty breathing or swallowing associated with the swelling?"

speaker: Patient
text:
"It's not really hard, it feels more like...I don't know, it's hard to describe, but it's not hard like a rock or anything, more like...a solid mass, I suppose. It's not really soft either, it's just...a firmness to it, that's the only way I can describe it."

"No, I don't think so, I can still breathe and swallow normally, but like I said, when I'm wearing my jacket or tie, it feels like it's pressing against my skin a bit, so I have to be more careful about my movements around it."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request a neck X-ray to get a better look at the swelling. Can you please remove your clothing from the top of your neck and hold still for me so I can take a proper X-ray?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll remove my jacket and tie. *removes jacket and tie* I'll hold still, I don't want to move around or anything that might affect the X-ray."

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Can you tell me if you've noticed any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your arms or hands?"



Also, can you describe the color of the swelling, is it pale, red, or does it have a normal color?"



REQUEST TEST: Neck X-ray

speaker: Measurement
text:
RESULTS: 
- Numbness, tingling, or weakness in arms or hands: NORMAL READINGS
- Color of the swelling: Normal

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Thank you for the X-ray results. I see that the swelling appears to be a large, firm mass in the right neck. Can you tell me if you've noticed any recent trauma or injury to the area, such as a fall or a blow to the head?



Can you also tell me if the swelling is affecting your ability to move your head or neck freely?



Also, have you noticed any recent changes in your vocal cord function, such as hoarseness or a raspy voice?"

speaker: Patient
text:
"No, I don't think so, I haven't noticed any recent trauma or injury to the area. I did hit my head on a golf club a few weeks ago, but that was just a minor bump and I didn't think much of it at the time. I'm pretty sure it's not related to the swelling though."

"No, the swelling isn't really affecting my ability to move my head or neck freely, but I do feel like I have to be more mindful of it when I'm wearing my jacket or tie, like I mentioned earlier. It's just a bit of a nuisance, but I can still turn my head and move around normally."

"No, I haven't really noticed any changes in my vocal cord function, I've been able to speak and talk normally, but like I said, I do feel a bit more self-conscious about the swelling now that you've pointed it out. It's not really affecting my voice, but I do feel like I have to be more

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about the patient's activity level, has the swelling made it difficult for them to perform daily activities such as dressing, eating, or sleeping?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It's actually made it a bit more difficult for me to dress and undress, especially when I'm wearing my jacket and tie. I have to be more mindful of the swelling and make sure I'm not putting too much pressure on it. But it's not really affecting my ability to eat or sleep, I've just gotten used to it being there, like I said earlier."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, thank you for the X-ray results, it seems like we have a significant finding here. Can you tell me if you've noticed any recent changes in your voice, such as hoarseness or a raspy voice, as we noticed a potential connection to the vocal cords on the X-ray?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think so, I haven't noticed any changes in my voice, but like I said, I do feel a bit more self-conscious about the swelling now that you've pointed it out. It's not really affecting my voice, but I do feel like I have to be more mindful of it, especially when I'm speaking in front of others."

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Can you tell me more about the sensation of the swelling, is it hard, soft, or does it feel like a lump, and are there any areas where it feels particularly tender or sensitive?



Also, can you show me the exact location of the swelling, and how far down does it extend in your neck?



I'd like to request an ultrasound to get a better look at the swelling and assess its texture and consistency. Can you please remove your shirt and hold still for me while I take the ultrasound?"

speaker: Patient
text:
"It's a bit hard, like I mentioned earlier, but not hard like a rock, more like...a solid mass, I suppose. It's not really soft either, it's just...firmness to it, that's the only way I can describe it. As for where it extends in my neck, it's right at the back of my neck, near the base of the skull, and it feels like it's rooted to the bone, I suppose."

"Okay, I'd like to examine the swelling more closely. Can you lift your shirt up and I'll take a look at the exact location of the swelling?"

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Okay, I'd like to take a closer look at the swelling again and ask a few more questions. Can you slowly turn your head to the side so I can examine the swelling on the left side?



"Can you tell me if you've noticed any recent changes in your neck pain or discomfort, and if it's constant or only present when you do certain activities?



"Can you describe the sensation of the left side of your neck, is it similar to the right side or does it feel different?"



Also, I'd like to request an MRI of the neck to get a better look at the swelling and its relationship to the surrounding structures. Can you please hold still for me while I take the MRI?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll turn my head to the side... *turns head* It's similar to the right side, feels the same way, just a bit more tender to the touch, but that's about it. I've noticed the discomfort is more noticeable when I'm wearing my jacket or tie, like I mentioned earlier, but it's not constant, it's more of a gentle pressure feeling, not sharp or stabbing."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me if you've noticed any recent changes in your sleep patterns, have you been having trouble sleeping due to the swelling?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, I have to admit, I've been having a bit of trouble sleeping because of the swelling. It's not really keeping me up at night or anything, but I do find myself waking up a bit more often to adjust my position or take off my jacket and tie. It's not a big deal, but it's definitely affected my sleep a bit."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me if the sensation of the swelling on the left side of your neck is similar to the right side, or does it feel different?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It's similar to the right side, feels the same way, just a bit more tender to the touch, but that's about it. I've noticed the discomfort is more noticeable when I'm wearing my jacket or tie, like I mentioned earlier, but it's not constant, it's more of a gentle pressure feeling, not sharp or stabbing."

speaker: Doctor
text:

speaker: Patient
text:
"Okay, I'd like to examine the left side of the swelling more closely. Can you slowly turn your head to the other side so I can take a look?



I'd like to check the lymph nodes in your neck again, to see if the swelling is connected to the lymph nodes. Can you swallow for me?



I'd like to ask you some more questions about your medical history. Have you noticed any other symptoms or changes in your overall health since the swelling started?



I'd like to request a referral to a specialist, such as an oncologist or a neurosurgeon, to further evaluate the swelling and determine the best course of action. Can you tell me if you have any questions or concerns about this?"

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Okay, thank you for answering all my questions. Based on the patient's symptoms, X-ray results, and the physical examination, I'm going to take a closer look at the ultrasound results. 

Can you please come back in 10 minutes so I can review the results and discuss the diagnosis with you?"
